title: AB 1685
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 43016 of the Health and Safety Code is amended. A person violating provisions of Section 43016 of the Health and Safety Code may be subject to civil penalties up to $37,500 per action, with specific penalties for violations involving portable fuel containers or small off-road engines. Manufacturers or distributors may also face penalties for violations. Engines violating emission control laws may face a civil penalty of up to $500 per unit. The executive officer of the state board may require payment of the penalty and compliance with regulations for continued sale in the state. The state board will adjust maximum penalties for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Penalties collected will go to the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43151 of the Health and Safety Code is amended. Section 43151 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to require certification for new motor vehicles or engines in California. Penalties collected will be deposited in the Air Pollution Control Fund. This article exempts certain vehicles from regulations if acquired to replace a damaged or stolen vehicle, or transferred by inheritance or court decree. Vehicles exempt from regulations include those acquired to replace a damaged or stolen vehicle, or transferred by inheritance or court decree. This chapter does not apply to motor vehicles with a certificate of conformity under the federal Clean Air Act, originally registered in another state by a resident who moves to this state and provides evidence of previous registration. This exemption will be effective 180 days after regulations are adopted for certifying new direct import vehicles. Section 43154 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose a civil penalty of up to $37,500 for violations of emission control laws. Manufacturers or distributors may also be required to pay the penalty and ensure compliance with laws for continued sale of motor vehicles in the state. A dealer violating emission control laws may face a civil penalty of up to $10,000, which can be adjusted for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index. This adjustment is exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Any action to recover a penalty under this section shall be brought in the name of the people of the State of California in the superior court of the county where the violation occurred, by the Attorney General on behalf of the state board, or by the district attorney, county attorney, or city attorney. Penalties adjudged by the court shall be deposited in the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43211 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to require new motor vehicles in California to meet emission standards set by the state board. Manufacturers selling vehicles that do not meet these standards may face a civil penalty of up to $37,500 per violation. The civil penalty for failure to meet zero-emission vehicle credit requirements in California is capped at $5,000 per credit. The state board will adjust this penalty for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index. Any penalty recovered for failure to meet zero-emission vehicle credit requirements in California will be deposited into the General Fund. Section 43212 of the Health and Safety Code is amended accordingly. Section 43212 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose a civil penalty of up to $37,500 for each vehicle that does not comply with emission standards or test procedures in California. Non-compliant manufacturers or distributors may be required to pay penalties and make vehicles compliant before further sales in the state. The state board adjusts the maximum penalty for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Any penalty recovered is deposited into the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43214 is added to the Health and Safety Code. The state board may order a manufacturer of motor vehicles to comply with emissions configurations for certified vehicles. Compliance is required for continued sale in the state, with penalties deposited into the Air Pollution Control Fund.
